::Prowl::

Prowl feels himself going a bit drowsy as his spark approachs Iron 
Raptor's, his hands managing to keep a hold of her. His spark begins 
the merging procedure, but a completely unwelcome thought enters his 
mind.

His drowsy mind tries to get rid of the thought, but without success. 
What if Dinobot held Iron Raptor like this? Would she enjoy it, more 
than she'd enjoy Prowl holding her? A wave of jealousy goes through 
Prowl, his spark making a tiny mistake in the merging....

A huge shockwave rocks the area as the sparks detonate, leveling the 
land around them.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The world slowly came into focus around Prowl, or rather not the 
world, but a black void. A bit confused, he looks ahead of himself, 
at a cluster of glowing spheres.

"Welcome, Prowl."

Prowl spins around to pinpoint the source of the voice, making a full 
360 degree turn and realizing that he didn't have a body, at least 
not a physical one. He could see, he could hear, but there was also 
something else. He could sense. He could sense the other 
conscioustnesses in the place, its vastnass, its complexity...

"Where am I?" Prowl's voice echos through the void, no barrier to 
slow it down.

"You should know that," the voice answers him. It was gentle, calm, 
and yet powerful, sounding like it knew all, but yet was always 
curious for more.

"The Matrix," he says, looking around in awe. The whole cluster of 
sparks seemed familiar, like he had seen it before sometime.

"Yes," the voice simply answers, giving Prowl the feeling that it 
knew his questions before he asked them. Prowl looked around in awe, 
feeling the sparks of many different ones.

"BlueStreak?" he suddenly says, sensing his brother among the 
sparks. "Why's he here?" he asks the voice.

"The Matrix has a different perception of time than normal bots do," 
the voice replies, "The shadows of every bot that has passed through 
here, and every bot that ever will, are still recognizable, faintly, 
but here."

Prowl thought over the answer for a while, suddenly realizing 
something.

"If I'm in the Matrix, that means ... the procedure was 
unsuccessful?" he asks, knowing what the answer was going to be 
before he finished asking the question.

"Yes."

Prowl's spark sinks, his next question leaving him before he could 
think about it. "And Iron Raptor?"

"She didn't end up here," the voice replies, "But she died in your 
arms, Prowl."

"No," Prowl chokes out. If he had a body, or even eyes in this realm, 
he probably would have cried. He had failed her, something must have 
gone wrong.. He wanted to yell out in anger, to curse himself for 
screwing up and letting Iron Raptor go, but the voice spoke again, 
this time with a soothing quality to it, sounding strangely 
compassionate.

"You did all you could, Prowl. She was merely too far gone for you to 
help."

"No!" Prowl exclaims, his anger at himself surfacing, "I didn't do 
all I could! I screwed up somewhere, or else she would be alive!"

"Calm yourself, Prowl," and now the voice took on a serious 
note, "There was nothing you could do for her."

"Is there nothing left to do for her, nothing at all?" Prowl almost 
begged, his spark holding on to a shred of hope.

"Well, that depends," the voice answers, Prowl's spark speeding up, 
the hope growing, "There is a way, but it would require you to give 
up half of who you are, so that she could live."

"Anything," Prowl says, his spark pounding. Iron Raptor might live 
after all!

"Anything does not include much, Prowl." the voice was serious, and a 
bit amused, "Are you willing to share your consciousness with her, to 
share a life source, to feel her feelings, to let her feel yours. She 
can survive yes, but you two will be living off of each other, and 
that's not always easy. Your consciousnesses will be tied together 
beyond seperation, and if one of you dies, so will the other. Are you 
willing to do that for her? Is she worth that much to you, Prowl?"

Prowl nods, certain of his answer. "Yes," his spark was ready to 
explode with joy, "Yes, anything for her to live."

"Are those true words?" the amusement was mostly gone, but the 
seriousness remained there, along with the curiousity, "Or words that 
you will forget as soon as she is alive in your arms?"

"True words," Prowl replies, "I will keep her safe all my life, I 
swear. I'll let her share my mind. I am willing to give myself up for 
her."

"Very well," the voice replies, "Then so you shall."

And then Prowl was spinning, spinning back into the world of the 
living, thrown back into his body.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Prowl opens his eyes, his optics focusing on the blue sky above. He 
sits up, looking at the grass around him.
